decision_conditions: Refused  - To carry out tree surgery, including a crown reduction by 2-3m, One Oak (T1 on application), To crown reduce by 3-4m One Oak (T7 on application), all within Area 1 on TPO 393.

Approved - To carry out tree surgery including, a reduction laterally by 2m, One Oak (T2 on application), To fell One Oak (T3 on application), To reduce the lowest limb growing towards the house by 2m, One Oak (T4 on application), To remove two lowest branches over the outbuildings, One Hornbeam (T8 on application), all within Area 1 on TPO 393.

7 Nicholas way is situated within a large plot with a number of large Oak trees. All the Oak trees have a high amenity value. The Hornbeam (T8 on application) is within the neighbours wooded area and as a result has a moderate amenity value. All the trees significantly contribute to the arboreal character of the Copse Wood Estate (Area of Special Local Character). The trees also contribute to local biodiversity and form part of the area of mature, protected trees that help to provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in the Copsewood Estate and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve (NNR). Apart from T3 on application (oak) the benefit in amenity and biodiversity afforded by these trees is both present and future because they have the potential for a long life expectancy.
With regards to the refused works T1 and T7 on application: Two Oak trees, One is situated within the front garden (T1) and one in the rear garden (T7). Both trees appear to be

The length of the lateral limbs of the trees to be pruned shall be tip-reduced as per the approved specification.. This work shall comprise a reduction in the length of the limb(s) in a uniform and systematic manner and the limb(s) should be cut back to suitably positioned secondary branches.

The work shall result in a tree of typical form for the species and of balanced appearance. The level of limb reduction shall be expressed either as a percentage / length of the overall limb length to be removed, or as a level of clearance to be provided.

The works shall be carried out in accordance with the recommendations contained in BS3998: 2010 - "British Standard Recommendations for Tree Work".  Climbing irons or 'spikes' shall not be used during the execution of the work.
In order to protect health of the tree and the visual amenity of the area.

No felling shall take place until such time as a scheme has been submitted to, and approved in writing by, the Local Planning Authority for a replacement tree, which shall be of 'Standard' size (about 2-3m high) and short-staked for support. The replacement tree shall be planted during the first planting season following the felling works hereby permitted. Thereafter, the replacement tree shall be retained indefinitely and maintained (watered and weeded during the spring and summer) for 2-3 years, or until established.
In order to comply with the requirements of Section 206 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.

Statutory crown lifting of trees: This does not require formal consent of the Council if the clearance only involves the removal of branches to give a separation between the footway and the tips of the lowest branches by up to 2.3m or the carriageway by up to 5.2m.
Owner(s)'s permission:  Permission should be sought from the owner(s) of the tree(s) and / or the owner(s) of the land that the tree(s) overhang prior to any approved work being carried out.

Expected standard of tree work: The approved works must be carried out in accordance with the conditions laid out above. If they are not, then enforcement action could being taken which could lead to prosecution and heavy fines. Therefore, it is highly recommended that the works are only carried out by a professional and competent arboriculturist who undertakes to comply with the conditions of this consent and in accordance with industry best practice (BS 3998:2010). The Arboricultural Association can provide details of its approved contractors, who have demonstrated such professionalism and competence, on their website (www.trees.org.uk) or by calling 01242 522152. Or on request the Council can provide a list of contractors who are known to carry out tree work to a good standard and to normally maintain an appropriate policy of indemnity insurance.
